To M
r
Secreta
r
28 Sep
t
89

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 28 Sep
t
To M
r
Secretary
It may please yo
r
H. to
e effect of that w
ch
yo
w
write by this bearer
I have delt w
th
e
gen
r
all states
in
e cause of
Vasseur,
& I send yo
r
heerinclosed
e coppy of my speeche. they sent yt p
ntl
ly to
e
states of
Zeeland
. to require theyr advise, & in respect of attending theyr answer
this matter hath had but a slow dispatche. the states of Zeland have
charged
e prisoners a fresh but to
e self same effect as before.
uppon oth
r
of his letters, w
ch
have bin lately sent unto them from
e
ministers of
Berchem
upon
e receat of those l
re
s
e gen
r
all states
sent unto mee to let them have a sight of her
Ma
tyes
commision
for my dealing in
e cause, w
ch
motion
ceeded as I have since
bin informed very certainly for
t
theyr Deputyes or some others
out of
England
hath intimated unto them that yo
r
H. letter was
cured
by favo
r
w
th
out her Ma
tyes
privity. Theyr manner of sending to see my
commission, as I told theyr messenger was very straunge, consydering
they had never used yt before, & knew right well
t
I was here
for no oth
r
purpose, but for
e proposing & furdering of hir Ma
ties
causes, &
t
in a matt
r
of such moment I wold not dare to
deale w
th
out hir Hig
nes
warrant, & th
r
upp
o
signifyed
t
it was
in theyr choyse to beleave or not to beleave mee. I wold not p
r
judice
so much
e credyt of my place as to showe my commission.
Nev
r
eles yf any of them for his private satisfaction would come
unto me I would in co
r
tesy im
te yt unto him. Wh
r
upp
o
meeting
after w
ch
Vansbergen,
one of
e Deputies for
e states of Zeland
w
th
wh
o
I conferred to such purpose, as yt were to tedyous to
repeate to yo
r
Ho. I shewed him yo
r
letter writt
e
unto mee in hir
Ma
tyes
name, alleadging
t
yt was not hir Ma
tyes
course to write
in ev
r
y cause w
th
hir owne hand; to hir Agent
or
s
vant
& I wished him to be a meanes in
e assembly
t
they would
surcease upp
o
such feeb le pretences to crosse hir Ma
tyes
request
, especially now
t
I thought hir Hig
nes
was indeed to
give
em good contentment in many thing
[beioynd] theyr
expectation. Upon my speech to Vansberg
e
&
my speech
his
suasyon
after
to them, they resolved not to use any former exception to my
commission, but made
t
answer w
ch
I send yo
r
H heerw
th
howbeyt I do apparantly
ceave both by theyr manner of
ceeding
& by other information,
t
if hir Ma
ty
will vouchsafe to
write hir owne Letter unto
em the prisoners shalbe released.
